comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment:
Are those methods needed just because of the Junit? Because if you want to test methods invocation order you could ignore the arguments on the test using something like:
(ScheduleBenefitPaymentDTO) any, (SelectedLeavePlan) any
So you can call new ScheduleBenefitPaymentDTO() in you mapper and no need to mock createScheduleBenefitPaymentDTO() on test

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment: I was moreso thinking of testing the mappings...i.e. that the right values are returned for the given key. The maps are the equivalent of an API i.e. instead of a whole load of if/elses (which you would test!)

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment: My concern in this class is the client can add more values to the enums list and those values won't be mapped because there isn't a way to do this.

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: It's a quite valid concern but to handle this issue we probably need a whole feature (out of the scope of this sprint), so I'll drop this issue and we can raise a Jira for this.

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment: I raised this at the meeting i had on Tuesday with the relevent parties & concensus is that there should be _very few_ enums that would need this type of mapping. More often than not we would / should be using the FDP enums where available, so no _custom_ mapping would be required.

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment: This statement is no longer valid after the last change.

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment:
The hole point of the abstract class was always to simplify the rules that extend it. If we just pass in the the most complex object everytime, the class starts to loose some of its reason to exist.
Each rule shouln't need to know from where the data should be retrieved from, it should be given.
Why can't we just pass in the objects that each rule will essentially need? The employment object and the end and start dates of the leave request?

comments.author: Gil Matias
comments.comment:
I supose this can be done.
Will do.
Will only commit after the demo.
This will not afect employeer rules.
I will retest them all on the on demand

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment: Java doc out of date. Either remove it or update it.

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment: Javadoc out of date. Either remove it or update it.

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment: This javadoc doesn't give an overall explanation of what the rule does...

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment:
Can you add some comments to explain what these are?
This was the rule that forced all other to have an applicable type descriptior name.
All the other have the same applicable type descriptor name and applicable type name. Why is this one different?
Why do we have two different fields with the same value in all the others?

comments.author: Gil Matias
comments.comment:
CBA and 1 or 2 others are diferent.
They refer to diferent fields and are used for diferent thimgs.
the text inside it just happens to be diferent

comments.author: Gil Matias
comments.comment: Correction: the text inside it just happens to be same in the other cases*

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment:
This behaviour was changed and the comment below no longer applies.
Why would a rule make an assessment just to be ignored by the engine?
Why is the rule returning an assessment in the first place?
Does this make sence? If it's a corner case, explain when it could happen.

comments.author: Gil Matias
comments.comment:
This was existing behavior before this refractor.
I supose this is something that could potentially happen due to bad DB config.

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment:
This behaviour added was under this commit: http://iedev317.development.fineos.com/reviewboard/r/72927/diff/1/
I either reopen the already closed review or I use this one to figure out why was this added.
The issue still stands: comment below no longer applies and why was this added?
We should't account for bad DB config. The very max we should do is throw and exception, not mask the problem.
I still don't understand why would a rule return an assessment and we discard it solely based on not having a name on the assessment. Why was an assessment returned in the first place?

comments.author: Tom Gurrie
comments.comment: we should really use xpath here and then have one method that you just pass the date to and it selects it - this way we can use it for any date

comments.author: Tom Gurrie
comments.comment: very specific \! If xpath was used you could call as many or few as you wanted

comments.author: Vinod Geeachan
comments.comment:
Hi Jemma,
Shouldn't we be including Javadoc?

comments.author: Tom Gurrie
comments.comment:
The Occupation stuff is getting a bit out of hand \!\!
By rights this shouldn't be in a support class, as it is, because you don't create the organisation.
I think the test should really CreatePerson() and then addOccupation(occDTO) and this will fill in the fields you need
Instead of dong the quickAdd and then editing, it might have been nice to just do an 'add' from the listview and pass down your dto values that you require

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment: _HoursworkedperweekTextfield_ should be called _HoursWorkedPerWeekTextfield_

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment:
What about Saturday & Sunday?
What about minutes?
Should we have an API on this DTO...setDefaultWorkingWeek which sets the hours to 8 & minutes to 0, monday to friday...means it could be reused & called from the test as opposed to hardcoding values

comments.author: Tom Gurrie
comments.comment: The elements with only one 'id' section are defined in AddOccupationPage. The others could be moved there simply by removing the widget id reference - use the example of jobTitle

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment:
Variables start with lowercase
This is only applicable for when we have one row in the calendar...we will probably have to look at refactoring this to be more dynamic...for the moment, it's probably good enough

comments.author: Tom Gurrie
comments.comment: was it not possible to have one method that referenced the field based on the day of the week - a single method could be used to enter the details e.g. getDay(MONDAY).sendKeys(AMOUNT)

comments.author: Jemma McCreesh
comments.comment: See Ashs first comment we know we have to refactor this we are trying to get basic path through before fleshing out the more complex options.

comments.author: Tom Gurrie
comments.comment: Unfortunately, JIRA is littered with refactoring jobs \! - the selenium is getting very complicated and a lot of teams are writing tests in the same area so it would be good o keep on top of it

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment: Same comment as above

comments.author: Tom Gurrie
comments.comment: Sorry Jemma, forgot at the time to mention this - we should really move this method off the work pattern page - there are loads of methods on AddOccupationPage that could be used and then you could subsequently add a work pattern or set up fields in the occupationDTO - give me a shout if you want to discuss

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment: Does this API assume that the organisation exists? What happens if it doesn't exist or will it always exist?

comments.author: Tom Gurrie
comments.comment: should be part of DTO

comments.author: Aisling Clinch

comments.comment: Should this be called _captureWorkPattern_ & set all the days (incl saturday & sunday), hours & minutes from the DTO

comments.comment: could these be on the work pattern dto ?

comments.comment: I don't think the createPerson should be here, after all you're on the 'person' occupation tab so you already have created the person. Other wise, bang on \!
